analysis.name: Paper Analysis
analysis.introduction: It is recommended printing some (or all) of the pages you have on an A3 format (or A4 if you don‚Äôt have this format). Because of the height of the page. you‚Äôll probably need to print some designs on multiple pages.

content.title: 1. Structure of the pages
content.description: Define the structure of the pages, the headers, the sections, the articles, main, footer outlining these on at least one printed page.

content.title: 2. Define headings
content.description: Find all the headings that structured a page, ensure the `H1` is not on the logo and that the logical order is followed. Most of the time, the H1 for the homepage will be hidden with CSS but needs to keep its legitimate meaning. That analysis should be done with the help of a SEO specialist in case you have one in your team.

content.title: 3. Find similar components
content.description: Try to find and regroup similar components giving them an individual name regarding their functionality and not just their context. For example, naming a tab system.

content.title: 4. All layout elements can be done with CSS
content.description: Most of the creative elements can today be done using CSS. Today, it is not recommended to create any layout element using images. Any simple graphical element like buttons or borders should be done in CSS to avoid performance or scalability issues.

content.title: 5. Check lack of coherence
content.description: Find some possible lack of coherence, in case a Styleguide was not provided by the creative team, it‚Äôs your responsibility to ensure that every graphic element belong to a possible category (Buttons, Typography, Sliders‚Ä¶). It‚Äôll help you to create your own CSS / Sass architecture or to identify which component you‚Äôll need from an identified CSS Framework.

content.title: Plugins defined before start coding
content.description: According to the specifications, plugins needed were defined in an early stage. Having a pre-list of possible plugins before starting the development can help the developer to stay focus and not spend too much time in doing research during the development phase. Obviously, some plugins may not perfectly fit and will be changed accordingly.

content.title: Medias / Images
content.description: All medias can be cut and saved before starting the development phase. That can help you to avoid back and forth between your creative software and your code editor.

content.title: Image folder architecture
content.description: The image folder has a clear architecture where you  arranged the layout's images. It is important to stay consistent between projects in general. Defining a structure for that folder and a naming convention can be helpful.

content.title: Image naming convention
content.description: A naming convention is used like adding prefixes to diferenciate types of images, all images used for background can be prefixed by `bg-`, icons by `icon-`, hero banners by `hero-` or `banner-` and so on.

content.title: Grid
content.description: A grid is explicitly provided in the design, and the details of the grid are present in the technical specification (width, gutters, number of columns‚Ä¶).
content.detail: The Web Designer can keep the grid in a transparent layer and use it on all his project.

content.title: Familiarity with the grid
content.description: Be familiar with the grid system you‚Äôll use on your project. Most of the time, some options (like alignment, offsetting, nesting‚Ä¶) are ignored by the developer and tend to be replaced by manual padding or margin unnecessarily.

content.title: Build every templates first
content.description: Before working on each components of your website, you can build every templates used in the creatives only with the grid classes. Building the structure before everything else, will facilitate your work afterwards.

content.title: Naming colors
content.description: All colors used in the creatives are named ($gray-light, $gray-dark, $green) or accordingly with their use ($body-background, $body-copy, $text-paragraph‚Ä¶).
content.detail: They can be exported in an ACO file (if use Photoshop or on a symbol page for Sketch) and shared with the developers.

content.title: Color state
content.description: The different color state of some elements (like buttons, links, inputs...) are defined and worked in the context of a light or dark background and with a light or a dark text

content.title: Color accessibility
content.description: All or the most important/used colors are accessible in the design to allow a fluid navigation on the website/webapp

ressources.title: Color Safe - accessible web color combinations
Coolors.co - The super fast color schemes generator

requirements.name: Fonts and texts
requirements.introduction: Fonts are an essential part of every design, they shouldn‚Äôt be chosen without discernment. Choosing the wrong font for a project could have financial and legal impacts. It is recommended to ask your client to buy these fonts to avoid possible future issues and take into consideration the condition of use. Some webfonts are limited in terms of pageviews and can‚Äôt be hosted.

content.title: Fonts format
content.description: The fonts for desktop (TTF or OTF in general) and the webfonts, in WOFF, WOFF2 and TTF format were provided.
content.detail: (in a Zip file or given access to the website where they were bought)

content.title: Fallback fonts
content.description: stacks were specified in a document (ideally the Style Guide) to the Front-End Developer.

documentation.title: CSS Basics: Fallback Font Stacks for More Robust Web Typography | CSS-Tricks

tool.title: Create Your Own @font-face Kits ¬ª Font Squirrel

content.title: Fonts weight
content.description: The total weight of the all webfonts don‚Äôt exceed 1-2 Mo (all variants included: italic, bold etc).

content.title: Avoid Lorem Ipsum
content.description: As far as possible, all texts are provided in the the proper language instead of dummy texts in English (Lorem Ipsum and affiliates).
content.detail: In case of a multilingual website, always ask yourself how the design can react if the text is longer than it was previously define. Remember that Web Designers use to create perfect designs and don‚Äôt always think about possible issues or situation with too much text.

ressources.title: Web Font Optimization ¬†|¬† Web Fundamentals ¬†|¬† Google Developers

content.title: Links state
content.description: All links have a default, hover, focus, active and visited state clearly defined (the Style Guide is the best document to specified these).

content.title: Navigation state
content.description: Alternate views of all navigation states (hover, active/current page)

content.title: Favicon image
content.description: A favicon image with at least 512px X 512px is provided in PNG format. The generation of all the others Favicons can be easily done with online tools.

tools.title: Favicon Generator for all platforms: iOS, Android, PC/Mac...

content.title: SVG format
content.description: All icons are provided in SVG format, each in the same square dimension, in black and in a separated folder.

content.title: Section title
content.description: Every section of the form possess a title (use as a legend html tag) and is clearly divided (using the fieldset html tag).

content.title: Inputs states
content.description: An example of the different states of all input fields were provided (at least focus and inactive/disabled state).

content.title: Error messages
content.description: All error messages were provided, the text (eventually in a separated document) the position and the color are clearly identifiable in the creatives and consistent. Some messages should be different according to the error.

content.title: Require/option indicator
content.description: All fields (input, checkbox, radio button, select...) possess an indicators of required/optional.

content.title: Primary and secondary buttons
content.description: The primary and secondary buttons are clearly identifiable and are used following common practices.

ressources.title: Primary & Secondary Action Buttons ‚Äì UX Planet

content.title: Button states
content.description: An example of the different states of a button were provided (Normal, hover, focused, pressed and inactive state).

content.title: Loading indicators
content.description: Buttons with built-in loading indicators are provided and can be applied to any button.

ressources.title: Design Better Input Fields ‚Äì UX Collective
Designing Perfect Text Field: Clarity, Accessibility and User Effort
Button UX Design: Best Practices, Types and States ‚Äì UX Planet
How To Design Better Buttons ‚Äî Smashing Magazine
Buttons in Design Systems ‚Äì EightShapes ‚Äì Medium

content.title: Mobile first
content.description: The mobile version of the design is provided before or at the same time of the desktop version.
content.detail: If the ‚Äúmobile first‚Äù thinking was not followed by the creative team, some irregularities and inconsistencies may appear between the mobile and the desktop version. Check and flag these issues before starting the development of the project

ressources.title: Official Google Webmaster Central Blog: Mobile-first Indexing

content.title: Tablet version
content.description: The tablet version of the design in most of cases should be provide too.

content.title: Component thinking
content.description: All components designed on each page were created with the component based approach (Atomic Design).
content.detail: If not, issues can occur in terms of performance, maintainability of the project...

content.title: Style Guide
content.description: A Style Guide needs to be provided listing all elements, components, styles, dimensions.
content.detail: Some boilerplates like UX Power Tools can help saving time and keep consistency in the designs.

ressources.title: The CodePen Design Patterns and Style Guide
Lonely Planet Travel Guides and Travel Information

content.title: Files to provide
content.description: For all websites, the web designer needs to provide at least 2 PSD (mobile, desktop and eventually tablet) or at least 1 Sketch file which needs to be delivered with the dimension below (if you have Photoshop CC 2015 and above, I recommend using artboards).
content.detail: Some web designers could eventually create multiple PSD corresponding to each components used and import them in a single PSD as ‚Äúsmart layer‚Äù. In that case, you‚Äôll have multiple PSD linked to one or two files. In the case of Sketch, since the libraries exist since version 47, it is possible to link multiples files with symbols.

content.title: Clean files
content.description: The creative files are cleaned before delivering to developers (empty and uneccessary layer needs to be removed to avoid large files).

content.title: Error pages
content.description: The 404 error (and eventually the page 500 error) page were designed.

content.title: Popins, popups and alert
content.description: All popins, popups and alert boxes were designed and can be enable throw layers of compositions.

ressources.title: Photoshop Etiquette: A Guide to Discernible Web Design

design-requirements.introduction: Designing a website or a webapp requires following some rules and taking into consideration that the project is not only a graphic project but a web project too. The next sections are crucial for any web project.

validation.introduction: The validation phase is when everything seems to be ready to be integrated. The client, in general, validate the creatives without waiting for any approval from the technical team. As exposed in the Design Checklist, it is essential that developers ensure the quality of the delivery before starting to code.

before-production.introduction: Before launching your website, be sure to review all your pages using the Front-End Checklist.
